result.markdown:
Welcome to the webpage of the practical sessions of the course **Apprentissage automatique et contrôle stochastique** taught by Professor [Pham](https://sites.google.com/site/phamxuanhuyen/) within the Master’s program in Probability and Finance (M2). ::: {#7bc4dc04 .cell fig-height='4' fig-width='6' output-location='column-fragment' execution_count=1} ``` {.python .cell-code} import os import sys from pathlib import Path # Import des Librairies import numpy as np import matplotlib.pyplot as plt import pandas as pd # Test print(np.arange(5)) def f(x) : return x**2 L=[i for i in range(-5,6)] plt.scatter(L,[f(l) for l in L]) plt.xlabel("Test") plt.ylabel("Test2") plt.title("Test Scatter Plot") plt.grid() # Exemple simple de DataFrame data = { 'Nom': ['Alice', 'Bob', 'Charlie', 'David'], 'Âge': [24, 30, 18, 22], 'Ville': ['Paris', 'Lyon', 'Marseille', 'Toulouse'], 'Score': [85.5, 90.0, 78.0, 88.5] } # test_pytorch_mlp.py import torch import torch.nn as nn print("Hello") # ----------------------------- # Définition du modèle # ----------------------------- class MLP(nn.Module): def __init__(self, input_dim, hidden_dims, output_dim): super().__init__() layers = [] in_dim = input_dim for h in hidden_dims: layers.append(nn.Linear(in_dim, h)) layers.append(nn.ReLU()) in_dim = h layers.append(nn.Linear(in_dim, output_dim)) self.network = nn.Sequential(*layers) def forward(self, x): return self.network(x) # ----------------------------- # Instanciation du modèle # ----------------------------- input_dim = 3 hidden_dims = [64, 64, 64] output_dim = 1 model = MLP(input_dim, hidden_dims, output_dim) # ----------------------------- # Affichage de l'architecture # ----------------------------- print("\n=== Architecture du modèle ===\n") print(model) # ----------------------------- # Nombre de paramètres # ----------------------------- num_params = sum(p.numel() for p in model.parameters() if p.requires_grad) print("\nNombre de paramètres entraînables :", num_params) # ----------------------------- # Test forward (sanity check) # ----------------------------- x = torch.randn(5, input_dim) y = model(x) print("\nEntrée x.shape :", x.shape) print("Sortie y.shape :", y.shape) print("\nSortie y :\n", y) df = pd.DataFrame(data) df ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [0 1 2 3 4] Hello === Architecture du modèle === MLP( (network): Sequential( (0): Linear(in_features=3, out_features=64, bias=True) (1): ReLU() (2): Linear(in_features=64, out_features=64, bias=True) (3): ReLU() (4): Linear(in_features=64, out_features=64, bias=True) (5): ReLU() (6): Linear(in_features=64, out_features=1, bias=True) ) ) Nombre de paramètres entraînables : 8641 Entrée x.shape : torch.Size([5, 3]) Sortie y.shape : torch.Size([5, 1]) Sortie y : tensor([[-0.1689], [-0.1913], [-0.1728], [-0.1429], [-0.1120]], grad_fn=) ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=1} ```{=html}
Nom Âge Ville Score
0 Alice 24 Paris 85.5
1 Bob 30 Lyon 90.0
2 Charlie 18 Marseille 78.0
3 David 22 Toulouse 88.5
``` Test scatter plot ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/cell-2-output-3.png){} ::: ::: ## Global informations {.unnumbered} :::{#method-description .methodology} Prerequisites : The **prerequisites** for this course are the following: - Good knowledge on **Probability Theory** and **Stochastic Processes**. - Basics on **optimal control theory**. - Basics on **Deep Learning**. - Familarity with **Python** and potentially with **PyTorch**. Schedule : The practical sessions will take place on $\ldots$ each time in **room 15/25 104** at Jussieu and will be divided into three 3-hour sessions, each illustrating the concepts covered during the lecture. Materials : The practical sessions will be conducted in **Python**. You should bring your own laptop and have your own Python environment set up for each session. Planning : - Lab work n°1 : About **Deep PDE Solver** for solving partial differential equations. - Lab work n°2 : About **Reinforcement Learning** for stochastic control problems. - Lab work n°3 : About **Generative IA** and **Schrodinger Bridge** for data generation. Grade : To be confirmed Questions ? : If you have any **questions**, you can either e-mail [Samy](mailto:samy.mekkaoui@polytechnique.edu) or [Alexandre](mailto:alexandre.alouadi@polytechnique.edu) who prepared the lab sessions for this course. ::: ## Use this website {.unnumbered} :::{#method-description .methodology} Structure of the website : The site is structured into three sections that make up the course, each consisting of two chapters. - Course reminders: The first chapter, titled **Course reminders**, presents the key theoretical concepts. - Practical session: The second chapter, titled **Lab work** contains the practical session instructions and a link to a **Jupyter notebook file** where you can write your code. te that the Jupyter notebooks files are designed to be **self-sufficient**, allowing you to work independently during the practical sessions. - References: The site contains a section **References** - Appendix: The site contains also a section **Appendix** where we go more in depth about some topics discussed during the course. For your information, this site is generated using [Quarto](https://quarto.org) through GitHub Pages (see this [GitHub](https://github.com/SamyMekk/TP-Controle-Stochastique) page). If you spot any errors on the site, feel free to report them through pull requests. ::: ## Acknowledgements {.unnumbered} :::{#method-description .methodology} We would like to thank the following individuals and organizations without whose support this course would not be possible - Professor [Huyên Pham](https://sites.google.com/site/phamxuanhuyen/) for the support and valuable feedbacks during the creation of this lab. - **Participants** in the course of your interest in Machine Learning for stochastic control and its applications. :::
